results.name: Triangle read by rows: T(n,m) (n>=m>=1) = domination number for kings' graph on an n X m toroidal board.
comment: That is, the minimal number of kings needed to cover an n X m toroidal chessboard so that every square has a king on it, is under attack by a king, or both.
For the usual non-toroidal case, the formula is ceiling(m/3)*ceiling(n/3).
reference: John J. Watkins, Across the Board: The Mathematics of Chessboard Problem, Princeton University Press, 2004, pages 144-149.
link: Dan Freeman, Chessboard Puzzles Part 4 - Other Surfaces and Variations.
mathematica: Flatten[Table[Ceiling[Max[m Ceiling[n/3], n Ceiling[m/3]]/3],{n, 1, 13}, {m, 1, n}]] (* _Indranil Ghosh_, Mar 09 2017 *)
program: for(n=1,20,for(m=1,n, print1(T(n,m)", "))) \\ _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Dec 16 2016
